qŭi subdit pòpulum meum sùb me. ^ My mercy
column8: and I have hoped in him
column9: who subdueth my people under me.

qŭi dòcet manûs meas ad práĕlium: qŭia innotuìsti ei~? Aŭt fílius hòminis
that thou art made known to him~? or the son of man
column6: that thou makest account of him~?

1 ^ Benedìctus Dòminus Deus meus: 4 ^ Hòmo vanitáti sìmilis factus èst~; dies ejus sicut ùmbra praĕtèreunt. ^ Man is like to vanity~; his days pass away like a shadow.

who teacheth my hands to fight: bow down thy heavens and descend~; touch the mountains

qŭi dòcet manûs meas ad práĕlium: et dissipábis eos~; emìtte sagìttas tuas
et dìgitos meos ad bellum. ^ Blessed be: et conturbábis eos. ^ Send forth lightning
who teacheth my hands to fight: and thou shalt scatter them~; shoot out thy arrows

et dìgitos meos ad bellum. ^ Blessed be: et líbera me de aqŭîs mùltîs
^ Put forth thy hand from on high
column7: and deliver me from many waters
column8: from the hand of strange children

qŭi dòcet manûs meas ad práĕlium: et dèxtera eórum dèxtera iniqŭitátis. ^ whose mouth hath spoken vanity
et dìgitos meos ad bellum. ^ Blessed be: and their right hand is the right hand of iniquity.

qŭi dòcet manûs meas ad práĕlium: cánticum novum cantábo tìbi~; in psaltério
I will sing a new canticle~; on the psaltery and an instrument of ten strings I will sing praises to thee

qŭi dòcet manûs meas ad práĕlium: qŭi redemìsti Davídem servum tuum de gládio malìgno. ^ who givest salvation to kings~; who hast redeemed thy servant David from the malicious sword.
et érue me de manu filiórum alienórum
column6: and rescue me out of the hand of strange children
column8: and their right hand is the right hand of iniquity

1 ^ Benedìctus Dòminus Deus meus: 12 ^ quórum fílii sicut novèllaĕ plantatiónes in juventúte sua. Fíliaĕ eórum compòsitaĕ~; circumornátaĕ ut similitúdo templi. ^ whose sons are as new plants in their youth. Their daughters decked out
qŭi dòcet manûs meas ad práĕlium: adorned round about after the similitude of a temple.
eructántia èx hoc in illud. Oves eórum foĕtósaĕ
et dìgitos meos ad bellum. ^ Blessed be: abundántes in egrèssibus suîs. ^ Their storehouses full
who teacheth my hands to fight: flowing out of this into that. Their sheep fruitful in young

1 ^ Benedìctus Dòminus Deus meus: 14 ^ Boves eórum crassaĕ. Non èst ruína macèriaĕ
et dìgitos meos ad bellum. ^ Blessed be: nèqŭe clamor in plassîs eórum. ^ Their oxen fat. There is no breach of wall
nor crying out in their streets.

qŭi dòcet manûs meas ad práĕlium: cui haĕc sùnt~; beátus pòpulus cujus Dòminus Deus ejus. ^ They have called the people happy
et dìgitos meos ad bellum. ^ Blessed be: that hath these things~; but happy is that people whose God is the Lord.
